title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: The sun mounted above the " Black Hill," andas it crossed the meridian dispelled the remnantsof the previous night's mist. But it was notuntil the orb of Ught had got well home to thewest, that one by one the smugglers wakened,and about an hour before sunset were againmounted and on their northward journey.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: It was a great howff o' Mr. Soulis's, onyway ; there he would sit an' consider his sermons ; and indeed it's a bieldy bit. Weel, as he cam' ower the wast end o' the Black Hill, ae day, he saw first twa, an syne fower, an' syne seeven corbie craws fleein' round an' round abune the auld kirkyaird. They flew laigh and heavy, an' squawked to ither as they gaed; and it was clear to Mr. Soulis that something had put them frae their ordinar.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Abune Hangin' Shaw, in the bield o' the Black Hill, there's a bit enclosed grund wi' an iron yett ; and it seems, in the auld days, that was the kirkyaird o' Ba'weary, and consecrated by the Papists before the blessed licht shone upon the kingdom. It was a great howff o' Mr. Soulis's, onyway ; there he would sit an' consider his sermons ; and indeed it's a bieldy bit.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: About the end o' July there cam' a spell o' weather, the like o't never was in that country side ; it was lown an' het an' heartless ; the herds couldnae win up the Black Hill, the bairns were ower weariet to play ; an' yet it was gousty

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Seeing that I meant to dodge, he also paused; and a moment or two passed in feints on his part, and corresponding  movements upon mine. It was such a game as I had often played at home about the rocks of Black Hill Cove; but never before, you may be sure, with such a wildly beating  heart as now. Still, as I say, it was a boy's game, and I thought I could hold my own at it, against an elderly seaman  with a wounded thigh.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: There, too, is Minto Hill, as modest and shapely and smooth as Clytie's shoulders, and Earlston Black Hill, with Cowdenknowes at its foot ; and there, standing stark and upright as a warder, is the stout old Smailholme Tower, seen and seeing all around. It is quite curious how unmistakable and important it looks at what must be twenty and more miles.

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: There, too, is Minto Hill, as modest and shapely and smooth as Clytie's shoulders, and Earhton Black Hill, •with Cowdenknowes at its foot ; and there, standing stark and upright as a warder, is the stont old Smailholme Tower, seen and seeing all around. It is quite curious how unmistakable and important it looks at what must be twenty and more miles.

title: Mr. Hogarth's Will
author: Spence, Catherine Helen
snippet: I should like to try an experiment. Youknow that sand flat, that is worth very little but for scanty pasture,at the back of the Black Hill, as it is called. I would divide it intoallotments among the most industrious and energetic of myfarm-labourers, and show them the method pursued by the Flemishfarmers, and see if in the course of ten years they are not growing asgood crops as in the most favoured spots on the estate.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: " You are at the * Admiral Benbow,' Black Hill Cove, my good man," said I.
